page.title: Reflect before you start
page.contents:
This lesson is called Energy.  It will cover:

  • Different "types" of collisions
  • kinetic energy and internal energy
  • Solving elastic collision problems
  • Solving inelastic collision problems when we know the coefficient of restitution
  • The Law of Conservation of Energy (a first look - we will add more to this in later topic units)

Before you start to look at any complicated content, whether it is a textbook, a set of video lectures, a web page, whatever, it is a good idea to prepare to learn by doing a bit of reflection.  To develop the habit it is good to write some reflections.  In the space below write three things (sentences, point form, whatever you want) about what you are about to learn.  Here are some things you might write about below:

  • List things that you think you might learn about in the lesson (in more detail than was given in the list above).
  • List things that you already know about the topics of this lesson.
  • List things that you have heard about these topics, but don't understand.

page.title: Main page - choose lesson part
page.contents:
You do not have to finish the lesson all in one sitting.  You may reattempt it if you are not satisfied with how you did.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  This is partly because moodle has a tendency (which I haven't figured out) to skip the Reflective Writing parts of these lessons.  This map will help you see if you have missed any and find your way to where they should be.

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

answer.answer_text: All Reflective Writing Pages: This is a fail safe in case the lesson navigation fails and you can't view on of the Reflective Writing pages. Normally there should be no need to click this.

page.title: Online Lecture 5-1: Classifying Collisions
page.contents: Watch this online lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: What is conserved in elastic collision?
page.contents: In an isolated, elastic collision, where the system is the pair of colliding objects which of the following quantities remain unchanged?  (choose all that apply)

answer.response: Yes, momentum is conserved for any isolated collision
Yes, kinetic energy is unchanged in an elastic collision

answer.answer_text: The relative speed of one object relative to the other
answer.response: Yes, that's how we defined "elastic collision" in the first place

answer.answer_text: The relative velocity of one object relative to the other
answer.response: No. The relative velocity reverses direction during a collision (in one-dimension). So it changes.
No. The objects interact and so their momentums are changed

answer.answer_text: The kinetic energy of each object
answer.response: No. The objects are able to exchange kinetic energy during the collision

page.title: Match collision type to description
page.contents: Match each description to the correct collision type.

answer.answer_text: momentum and kinetic energy are both conserved

answer.response: momentum is conserved, relative speed decreases
momentum is conserved, relative speed after the collision is zero
momentum is conserved, relative speed increases
neither of momentum nor kinetic energy is conserved

page.title: End of cluster 5-1
page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: Online Lecture 5-2: Internal Energy (Part 1)
page.contents: Watch this online lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Which is reversible?
page.contents:
Consider the following two processes:

1. A mass hanging on the end of a spring moves down. This stretches the spring.

2. A stone falls, hits the ground, and comes to rest. It leaves a dent in the ground.

Which of these processes is reversible?

answer.response: No.  Think about what process 2 would be like if it happened backwards.  The ground would spontaneously "undent" itself and shoot the rock up into the air.  Have you ever observed this to happen?  Do you think it is possible?
No.  Think about the mass on the spring.  What is the next thing that is about to happen (if you keep watching the mass after it has completed its downward trip)?

No.  Think about what process 2 would be like if it happened backwards.  The ground would spontaneously "undent" itself and shoot the rock up into the air.  Have you ever observed this to happen?  Do you think it is possible?

page.title: Online Lecture 5-2: Internal Energy (Part 2)
page.contents: Watch this video lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Did internal energy increase?
page.contents: A piece of clay is thrown at a wall.  It sticks to the wall.  Consider the system to be the clay and the wall.  Did the internal energy of the system increase, decrease, or stay the same?

answer.response: Remember that our hypothesis is that when kinetic energy is lost by a system, it doesn't disappear.  It turns into another kind of energy that we are calling "internal energy".  The piece of clay slowed down (in fact it stopped).  So, it lost kinetic energy.  What does this imply about the internal energy of the system?

Remember that our hypothesis is that when kinetic energy is lost by a system, it doesn't disappear.  It turns into another kind of energy that we are calling "internal energy".  Has this system lost or gained kinetic energy?

answer.answer_text: We can’t tell from the information given.
answer.response: We certainly can tell.  Remember that our hypothesis is that when kinetic energy is lost by a system, it doesn't disappear.  It turns into another kind of energy that we are calling "internal energy".  Has this system lost or gained kinetic energy?

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

page.title: What reverses sign
page.contents: We know that the relative speed of two objects remains unchanged during an elastic collision (by definition).  What happens to the x-component of the relative velocity during an elastic collision in one dimension?

answer.answer_text: It is unchanged (in one dimension the x-component velocity is the same as speed)
answer.response: No. The x-component of of velocity is *not* the same as speed. Components of vectors can be positive or negative, but speed is positive by definition.
No. You should probably look back at the last two lectures. You seem to have missed a crucial point.
No. You should probably look back at the last two lectures. You seem to have missed a crucial point.

answer.answer_text: We don't know. Speed is different from velocity, so the rule about the relative speeds tells us nothing about components of relative velocity.
answer.response: Speed is different from velocity. But they are closely related and so knowing that the relative speed is unchanged does tell us things about the components of the relative velocity.

page.title: Online Lecture 5-3: Elastic Collisions
page.contents: Watch this online lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Match collision types with coefficient of restitution
page.contents: Match each range of the coefficient of restitution with the appropriate collision/interaction type.

page.title: coefficient of restitution from v vs. t graph
page.contents: Here is the \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) graph for a cart collision.  What is the coefficient of restitution in this collision?

answer.response: No. Are the carts moving faster or slower relative to each other after than they were before? Remember that coefficient of restitution is \( v_{12f}/v_{12i} \).

No. Coefficient of restitution is defined in terms of relative speeds. You appear to be taking a ratio of the final speeds (relative to the coordinate system) rather than relative speeds. Also it is a ratio of the relative after over the relative speed before, but you seem to only be looking at the *final* velocity components.
No. Are you looking at the initial velocity components? You need to be looking at relative speeds and comparing after with before.
No, coefficient of restitution is positive by definition because it is a ratio of *speeds*. But you are so close that instead of asking you a different question the lesson will re-ask this question.

page.title: Online Lecture 5-4: Other Types of Collisions
page.contents: Watch this online lecture.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Applying the brakes
page.contents: You are riding your bike on a flat bit or road when you apply the brakes and stop. What has happened to the kinetic energy that you and the bike had before you applied the brakes?

answer.answer_text: It has been converted to thermal energy.
answer.response: Yes. Primarily what has happened is that the brakes and the rim of the wheel have warmed up.

answer.answer_text: It was conserved because every type of energy is always conserved.
answer.response: Energy is always conserved but individual types of energy are not. You have stopped so your kinetic energy has definitely "disappeared". It hasn't really "disappeared", though. It must have been transformed into another form of energy.

answer.answer_text: It flowed away into the ground.
answer.response: No. Energy doesn't really "flow". It isn't a liquid that moves around. Objects "have" energy and that energy can be transformed into different forms.

answer.answer_text: It was transformed into spring energy.
answer.response: Nope. There are no springs or other deformable "springy" objects here.

answer.answer_text: It kept going and left you behind.
answer.response: No. Energy isn't a physical object. It doesn't "go" anywhere. Objects have energy. So your energy can't "keep going without you". It has to have turned into some other form of energy.

page.title: Bumping into spring
page.contents: Springs of various sorts are often used to "cushion" impacts to prevent damage to various objects.  In a factory a heavy cart full of boxes to be shipped is rolling along a horizontal track.  At the end of the track is a big spring which brings the cart gently to rest.  The system is the cart plus spring.  As the cart runs into the spring and compresses it what is the main energy transformation that is taking place in the system?

answer.response: A bit of this is probably happening but it is not the main energy transformation taking place. What kind of energy results from compressing a spring?
No. The energy of the system is kinetic at the start of this process (the cart is moving). Energy is being converted *from* kinetic energy *into* spring energy.

No. There is probably some thermal energy produced in this process. But there is no spring energy at the start of the process so any thermal energy produced is not a result of a transformation from spring energy.
Spring energy is what we are ending up with in this process. But it isn't starting out as thermal energy. What is the main thing that the system is "doing" before this process?

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------First Half-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 5 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper.  Don't put your name on it; I would rather mark "blind".  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. In your own words, give a definition of the "state of a system".

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

------------End of Lesson-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. The idea of internal energy as a "measure of energy associated with the state of the system" might seem rather vague.  But it is not vague at all because we can measure changes in a closed system's internal energy.  Explain how we are able to measure changes in a closed system's internal energy (hint: the process is described in the videos and has to do with changing speeds).

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. In your own words, give a definition of the "state of a system".

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

page.title: What happens to relative velocity?
page.contents: For a collision in one dimension what happens to the relative velocity of one object relative to the other during the collision?

answer.response: No. Relative velocity is a vector. It is neither positive nor negative, so it can't reverse sign. The *component* of the relative velocity parallel to the direction of motion of the objects reverses sign.

Imagine you are moving towards something that you are about to collide with (for your sake I hope it is small and soft). You might describe its relative velocity with respect to you as "5 m/s towards me". After you collide with it is it possible that its relative velocity relative to you is still "5 m/s towards me"? I hope you see that it isn't possible. So the relative velocity can't remain unchanged during a collision, elastic or not.
No. You need to go back to Lecture 1 of this unit. You have missed a crucial point.

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. The idea of internal energy as a "measure of energy associated with the state of the system" might seem rather vague.  But it is not vague at all because we can measure changes in a closed system's internal energy.  Explain how we are able to measure changes in a closed system's internal energy (hint: the process is described in the videos and has to do with changing speeds).

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

page.title: match description to change in internal energy
page.contents: Match each description of a process to the type of change in internal energy which would be associated with it.

answer.answer_text: object deforms but is able to spring back to original shape
new types of material are formed during the process

page.title: End of cluster 5-2
page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

page.title: Piece of dough thrown at wall
page.contents: You throw a ball of bread dough at the wall (why would you do such a thing??).  It sticks to the wall.  During the collision between the dough and the wall did the internal energy of the dough-wall system increase, decrease or stay the same, and how do we know?

answer.answer_text: It increased. We know because kinetic energy of the dough must have been converted into another form within the system.
It increased. We know this because sound must have been produced during the collision between the dough and the wall.
answer.response: You are correct that it increased, but not about how we know. Remember that we are talking about the dough-wall system. The sound produced is something going on in the air, which is not part of the system, so it must represent some energy "leaving" the system. So it doesn't tell us that the internal energy of the system increased. What it does tell us is that the *total* energy of the system probably decreased, even if only slightly.

answer.answer_text: It decreased. We know this because the dough was moving before the collision and now it isn't. Clearly kinetic energy has been lost.
answer.response: No. Kinetic energy is not a type of internal energy. It is a different category of energy. You are correct that the kinetic energy decreased. So, what happened to that "lost" kinetic energy...?

answer.answer_text: It decreased. We know this because the dough compressed during the collision (so the system size decreased) and internal energy is an extensive quantity.
answer.response: No, although that brings up subtle points about what we mean by "system size" when we talk about extensive quantities. It is certainly possible that the dough was compressed during the collision. But what we really mean by system size is "amount of matter", not volume. The amount of dough did not change so the system size was unchanged.

answer.answer_text: It stayed the same because energy is always conserved.
answer.response: Energy is always conserved, but it can be transformed from one form to another (as we will discuss in another few lectures). So the amount of internal energy can change. It just means that some other kind of energy also has to change to compensate.
